page.title: 03INTRODUCTION-Topography
page.content: The block can be split into two natural areas. To the south and west the land is mainly flat or undulating while to the north and east there lies a series of low hills. Towering over the village of Penshaw and the rest of the block is Penshaw Hill (136m) with the dominant Monument to the first Earl of Durham perched on top. The hill forms the western edge of the East Durham {Permian Escarpment,}a low plateau of magnesium limestone which is also seen exposed at Hastings Hill (124m) and Herrington Hill. At these three sites the limestone has in the past been quarried forming sites of natural intrest. Underlying the limestone and forming the low plain to the west can be found {Carboniferous Coalmeasures}providing the coal that gave the NE its wealth.
